title: 0 DTE SPX Best Entry Time

00:00 - Introduction
   - Purpose of the video
   - Overview of zero DTE trading in SPX

01:00 - Common Misconceptions
   - Discussion on entering trades in the last hour
   - Comments from previous video on optimal entry times

02:30 - Methodology and Data
   - Explanation of data sources and analysis process
   - Importance of using a large dataset from SIBO

04:00 - Overview of Trading Data
   - Introduction to the dataset and key metrics
   - Differences between 0935 and 1500 entries

05:30 - Analysis of Iron Condors
   - Performance comparison of single options vs. iron condors
   - Impact of adding five delta wings to positions

08:00 - Hourly Entry Performance
   - Performance of entries at different times throughout the day
   - Trends observed in data from 2022 to 2024

10:00 - Importance of Entry Time
   - Better performance of trades entered closer to market close
   - Volatility and order flow in the first hour of trading

11:30 - Yearly Analysis
   - Comparison of performance in 2022 (bear market) vs. 2023 (bull market)
   - Shifts in optimal entry times between different market conditions

13:00 - Key Observations
   - Differences in max loss and average P&L between 2022 and 2023
   - Unexpected findings in loss sizes and win rates

14:30 - General Conclusions
   - Later entries tend to perform better
   - Strangles outperform straddles in recent years

15:30 - Future Considerations
   - Potential for further analysis on profit and loss management
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and suggestions for future videos

17:00 - Conclusion
   - Summary of key points
   - Encouragement to like and subscribe

text: What is the best time to enter a zero DTE trade in SPX? Well, we're going to get to the bottom of that, and we're going to answer a couple of questions along the way that people commonly get wrong. So buckle up, we're going to look through over 25,000 trades from 2022, and we are going to get to the bottom of this question. Let's get straight in. So first thing is first, contrary to popular belief, like this person says down here, you never put on an iron condor or premium selling strategy with zero DTE one hour before the close. They're referencing a previous video that I did where I was entering the last hour before the close. And if you guys know anything about me, there's probably a reason why I was doing that, which will learn more about this person up here, commented on that same video, and they were saying commonly people open a trade a bit after market open. Did you discover something that made you decide otherwise? And I want you to keep that in mind as we move through this. Now, a couple notes on methodology. This is nothing super complex. I track zero DTE data because I trade it myself, but for something like this where we're going to look through a bunch of different permutations of strategies, I already have a data set that I've purchased from Cebo, intraday with full Greeks, and I run it through Python, and

So let's take a look at what this looks like. So we'll give her to those two and what I want to start us with is kind of an overview. And there's a reason why I want to start with this overview. It's specifically because it will help you identify some trends that I want you to see from the beginning. And then we're going to move into each individual year. Now, why did I pick 2022? Pretty simple. That's when the zero DTE expiration is kind of expanded. And it wasn't just a Friday expiration, but we started having midweek expirations. And then after 2022 is when we actually fully launched daily expirations. So this gives us kind of the purest sense that we can. I have larger data sets that we've looked at previously, but this is looking more closely at zero DTE specifically. Now, the other thing to keep in mind is 2022 and 2023 were important years. 2022 was a down year in SPX, just shy of 20 and then 2023 was a positive year in the SP 500 just over 23. Okay, so a common complaint that I got from my last video is that I didn't include iron condors, which you might expect. There's a reason why, but to satiate those people, let's take a look at those. Okay, so first things first, we notice that 0 935 for the single option variations perform worse than the later entries. Then we also notice that if you add five delta wings to all of these, they're all losing positions. So it takes something that previously was profitable and it makes it not profitable. Now if we look at the best performing iron condor, which was short, the 30 delta's long the five entered at 1500 Pacific time. The best performer was a returned 18,626, not bad. Now what I want to highlight about that though is if you look at the worst performing single option variant, the 10 delta entered at the same time, that returned 2522. The other thing I want you to notice is take a look at the max loss. The max loss in this 10 delta was 4600 bucks. The max loss for this 30 delta with the five wings was 3880. So

text: perform at least better on the further out of the money strikes. So the 10 delta, they perform better later on the day. Now there's a bit of an uptick here in this 12 Eastern time bracket where you can see this actually does well. It doesn't quite perform as well as the 141500 entries on average, but it's still noteworthy. And what we'll do next is look year by year, but a couple things to know again, this is with no management applied that actually changes things quite a bit. However, when you look at stuff like this and let me get myself out of the way for you, when you look at stuff like this, it's really important to know to few things. What we see in this back test is what we call in sample. This is when we look at a specified sample and we know what happened so we can, you know, see what's optimal for that. But you run the risk of overfitting overfitting is where our future results, we know will be different. And if we make our approach fit historic data perfectly, it runs the risk of not adjusting well to what things look like in the future, which is unknown to us. So to avoid overfitting what we want to do is look for trends that generally hold true across periods across delta's and make some informed decisions about what the future might look like based on that. You can run

text: tend to not perform well. Why is that a bunch of different reasons, but a lot of it comes down to the first hour of the market is very volatile. There are a lot of orders resting from the night before that are getting pushed through from pension funds that need to clear out their trades and so on and so forth. They're not really caring about getting optimal fill. So they're just blasting stuff through. This is where everything is digested quickly. So the first half hour to hour of a market tends to be pretty busy. The other thing is because there are now daily explorations, you'll notice that the rate of decay is actually a little bit slower in the beginning of the day relative to the end of the day. And it's the same thing that you'll see with options in general where it gets as parabolic as you can into expiration. But that's just happening on a shortened zero DTE timeframe. So when you're entering these things first thing right on the open, you're going to see more money. You're going to see a higher premium received, but a lot of that's not actually going to decay out for again relative to a zero DTE timeframe until later in the day. So you're really holding things exposing yourself to a lot of directional risk unless you're delta hedging and gamma hedging these positions, which SPX is very difficult to do. In any sort of pure

   - Differences between 0935 and 1500 entries

05:30 - Analysis of Iron Condors
   - Performance comparison of single options vs. iron condors
   - Impact of adding five delta wings to positions

08:00 - Hourly Entry Performance
   - Performance of entries at different times throughout the day
   - Trends observed in data from 2022 to 2024

10:00 - Importance of Entry Time
   - Better performance of trades entered closer to market close
   - Volatility and order flow in the first hour of trading

11:30 - Yearly Analysis
   - Comparison of performance in 2022 (bear market) vs. 2023 (bull market)
   - Shifts in optimal entry times between different market conditions

13:00 - Key Observations
   - Differences in max loss and average P&L between 2022 and 2023
   - Unexpected findings in loss sizes and win rates

14:30 - General Conclusions
   - Later entries tend to perform better
   - Strangles outperform straddles in recent years

15:30 - Future Considerations
   - Potential for further analysis on profit and loss management
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and suggestions for future videos

17:00 - Conclusion
   - Summary of key points
   - Encouragement to like and subscribe
